{{Infobox artist | name = Serkan Özkaya | image = Baker's Apprentice (self portrait).jpg | imagesize = | caption = Serkan Özkaya as ''Baker's Apprentice''
in a self-portrait from 2006 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1973}} | birth_place = Turkey | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Turkey|Turkish]], [[United States|American]] | movement = | awards = [[MacDowell Colony]], [[Society of Newspaper Design]], [[Civitella Ranieri]] | patrons = | field = [[Contemporary art]], [[Conceptual art]] | training = [[Bard College]], [[Istanbul University]] | works = [[David (inspired by Michelangelo)]] | influenced by = | influenced = }} '''Serkan Özkaya''' (1973) is a [[Turkish Americans|Turkish-American]] [[Conceptual art|conceptual artist]] whose work deals with topics of [[Appropriation (art)|appropriation]] and reproduction. He typically operates outside of traditional art spaces and often makes multiple versions of even his own work including his most noted work [[David (inspired by Michelangelo)]]. Özkaya's artworks are held in the permanent collections of the [[İstanbul Modern]] and [[Perili Köşk|Borusan Contemporary Art]] in [[Istanbul]], as well as three different [[21c Museum Hotels]] locations—[[Louisville, Kentucky]]; [[Bentonville, Arkansas]]; and [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. == Early life and education == Özkaya grew up in [[Istanbul|Istanbul, Turkey]]. At a young age, he began learning about [[Art of Europe|Western art]] through the study of reproductions of major artworks found in books. It is here his interests in the concepts originality, replication and emulation began.{{Cite web|url=https://www.stlbeacon.org/#!/content/13301/review_serkan_ozkaya_works_magic|title=Review: Serkan Ozkaya works magic|last=Cooper|first=Ivy|date=2008-10-07|website=STL Beacon|archive-url=https://archive.today/20150411222101/https://www.stlbeacon.org/%23!/content/13301/review_serkan_ozkaya_works_magic#!/content/13301/review_serkan_ozkaya_works_magic|archive-date=2015-04-11|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-09-08|df=}} He attended [[Istanbul University]], graduating with both a bachelor and a master's degree in arts.{{Cite web|url=http://magazine.art21.org/2011/07/01/inside-the-artists-studio-serkan-ozkaya/|title=Inside the Artist's Studio {{!}} Serkan Özkaya|last=Kotretsos|first=Georgia|date=2011-07-01|website=Art21 Magazine|access-date=2017-09-08}} He continued his graduate studies at [[Bard College]].{{Cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2009/04/another-handdrawn-newspaper.html|title=Serkan Ozkaya, Dave Muller and the hand-drawn newspaper|last=Knight|first=Christopher|date=2009-04-12|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-08}} After leaving Bard with a master's degree in fine art, he received an art fellowship at [[MacDowell Colony]]. Özkaya then returned to Istanbul University to study for his Ph.D. in German Language and Literature. In 2001, he published ''Genius and Creativity in the Arts'', a comparative study of the German works [[Moses und Aron]] (an opera by [[Arnold Schoenberg]]), [[Doctor Faustus (novel)|Doctor Faustus]] (a novel by [[Thomas Mann]]) and [[:de:Die Philosophie der Neuen Musik|Die Philosophie der Neuen Musik]] (a book by [[Theodor W. Adorno]]). == Career == === Notable works in serial form === ''Dear Sir or Madam'' (1996–2009) is a collection of letters and other correspondences between Özkaya and cultural institutions, dignitaries and curators. It is his own paper trail of bureaucracy in inaction. In the collection, among others, are his letters to the Louvre asking that he be allowed to hang the [[Mona Lisa]] upside down{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/15/arts/design/15serk.html|title=Serkan Ozkaya - Art - Report|last=Kennedy|first=Randy|date=2006-12-15|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-09-08|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} and a letter to the [[Bundestag|German Bundestag]] that they permit him to re-[[Christo and Jeanne-Claude#Wrapped Reichstag|wrap the Reichstag]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.berliner-zeitung.de/zeitgenoessische-kunst-aus-istanbul-im-haus-der-kulturen-der-welt-gewitzte-metaphern-16772842|title=Zeitgenössische Kunst aus Istanbul im Haus der Kulturen der Welt: Gewitzte Metaphern|last=Böker|first=Carmen|work=Berliner Zeitung|access-date=2017-09-08|language=de-DE}} Often, the letters do not deserve a response but curiously, they have usually been treated with official but unthinking courtesy, read perhaps but not comprehended—answered and then often passed along the bureaucratic chain. In 2009, ''Dear Sir or Madam'' was exhibited at the Slag Gallery in New York along with works from the same period. Among them was ''Proletarier Aller Laender'' (1998-2009) or ''Proletariat of all Countries'', as it is also known in English, a collection of red plastic foam figurines glued to the floor. In viewing this work, the audience is most likely forced to trample on the little figures as if to trample on the working classes. However, the [[proletariat]], which the figurines represent, in their resilience and ultimate power always springing back, indestructible.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} Other works in the exhibition included the golden sculptures ''Levitation by Defecation'' (2008), ''Shit on a Stick'' (2008), and ''Goldenboy'' (2006), "a fiberglass figure painted in gold acrylic and dangling a couple of feet off the ground by a noose". In 2000, Özkaya collected roughly 30,000 slides from artists, galleries, and institutions and showed them on one of the largest galleries in the main pedestrian street in Istanbul, at the Kazim Taskent Art Gallery. ''What A Museum Should Really Look Like (Large Glass)'' presented a giant mosaic of individual images. During the day the slides were readable from the inside of the gallery and at night, with the lights on, they became a scene for the street. This piece was later initiated in [[Utrecht|Utrecht, the Netherlands]] in a much larger scale with 100,000 slides.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} The collage of thousands of pieces of artwork was collected through an online advertisement. All of the works were arranged in the mosaic with no coherent order and no editorial or curatorial control from Özkaya.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/18/arts/art-review-politics-that-makes-peace-with-the-beauty-of-objects.html|title=ART REVIEW; Politics That Makes Peace With the Beauty of Objects|last=Cotter|first=Holland|date=2004-06-18|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-09-08|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} In 2003, Özkaya turned the front and back covers of the [[Turkish language]] newspaper, ''[[Radikal]]'' into drawings. This act enabled the reader to acquire a limited edition artwork for the price of the newspaper.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} In early 2004, it was part of a group exhibition named "The Poetics of Proximity" at the Guggenheim Gallery at [[Chapman University]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.ocweekly.com/arts/strange-land-6381040|title=Strange Land|last=Schoenkopf|first=Rebecca|date=2004-02-19|work=OC Weekly|access-date=2017-09-08}} In similar fashion, in subsequent years, some pages of several other newspapers were also hand-rendered and appeared as a print of the drawings. The overall piece, entitled ''Today Could Be A Day Of Historical Importance'' was executed in Sweden with ''[[Aftonbladet]]'', in Germany with Freitag,{{Cite web|url=https://www.freitag.de/autoren/der-freitag/kopierer-aller-lander|title=Kopierer aller Länder...|last=Arend|first=Ingo|date=2005-08-07|website=der Freitag|access-date=2017-09-08}} and in the US with ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[The Courier-Journal]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2009/04/10/kentucky-page-1a-turned-into-piece-of-newspaper-art/|title=Kentucky Page 1A turned into piece of newspaper art|last=Associated Press|first=|date=2009-04-10|website=The Denver Post|access-date=2017-09-08}} The last of which was created in collaboration with the non-profit artwithoutwalls.{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/04/10/louisvilles-emcourier-jou_n_185558.html|title=Louisville's Courier-Journal Front Page Completely Drawn By Artist|last=Shea|first=Danny|date=2009-05-11|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-09-08|language=en-US}} ''The New York Times'' version in the "Weekend Arts" section appeared ''[[mise en abyme]]'' with Özkaya's drawing appearing as an inset in the page and an even smaller drawing appearing as an inset of that, and so on, creating a [[Droste effect]].{{Cite web|url=http://graphics.nytimes.com/packages/pdf/magazine/serk.pdf|title=Weekend Arts: Fine Arts, Leisure|last=|first=|date=2006-12-15|website=The New York Times|access-date=2017-09-08}} [[File:Louisville, high class (7963849776).jpg|thumb|[[David (inspired by Michelangelo)]] in front of [[21c Museum Hotels|21c Museum Hotel]]]] In 2005, Özkaya created ''[[David (inspired by Michelangelo)]]'', a double-sized golden replica of [[Michelangelo]]ʼs [[David (Michelangelo)|''David'']] based on a 3D computer model by [[Marc Levoy]] of [[Stanford University]]. The sculpture was first intended to be part of the [[Istanbul Biennial#Participating artists at the 2005 Istanbul Biennial|9th International Istanbul Biennial]].{{Cite web|url=http://9b.iksv.org/english/?Page=Artists&Sub=Az&Content=Serkan_Ozkaya|title=Serkan Özkaya|last=|first=|date=September 2005|website=9th International İstanbul Biennial|access-date=2017-09-12}} Unfortunately, the statue crashed and was destroyed while in the process of being installed at [[Şişli|Şişli Square]]. Özkaya created two new versions of the replica at a studio in [[Eskişehir]], one of which was to be placed in the local Sazova Science, Art and Culture Park.{{Cite news|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/default.aspx?pageid=438&n=davut-sculpture-goes-to-kentucky-21c-museum-2011-09-19|title=Davut sculpture goes to Kentucky 21C Museum|last=Bozkurt|first=Göksel|date=2011-09-19|work=Hurriyet Daily News|access-date=2017-09-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150603192504/http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/default.aspx?pageid=438&n=davut-sculpture-goes-to-kentucky-21c-museum-2011-09-19|archive-date=2015-06-03|dead-url=yes}} The other was acquired by [[21c Museum Hotels]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.whas11.com/community/Giant-gold-replica-of-David-arrives-in-Louisville-149911335.html|title=Louisville residents react to giant, gold David statue|last=Ruper|first=Maggie|date=2012-05-02|work=WHAS11|access-date=2017-09-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130310103955/http://www.whas11.com/community/Giant-gold-replica-of-David-arrives-in-Louisville-149911335.html|archive-date=2013-03-10|dead-url=yes|df=}} On its way to Louisville, the piece made a stop in [[New York City]]. Although just a mere copy, the statue made quite a spectacle, as the artist intended, attracting the attention of tourists and residents as it was transported uncovered lying horizontally on a semi-trailer truck.{{Cite news|url=https://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/03/06/the-streets-were-his-gallery-space/|title=David Rolls Into Town, the Streets His Gallery|last=Barron|first=James|date=2012-03-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-09-12|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/03/07/giant-golden-statue-of-david-serkan-ozkaya-in-new-york-city-photos_n_1326739.html|title=Giant Golden 'David' Statue By Serkan Ozkaya Rolls Through The Streets Of NYC (PHOTOS)|date=2012-03-07|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-09-12|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/lacma-rock-will-we-ever-get-past-its-journey-and-focus-on-the-finished-sculpture-2174340|title=LACMA Rock: Will We Ever Get Past Its Journey and Focus on the Finished Sculpture?|last=Wagley|first=Catherine|date=2012-03-22|work=L.A. Weekly|access-date=2017-09-12}} The giant 30-foot statue is currently featured in front of the museum hotel on West Main Street in Louisville.{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/frank-browning/naked-david-storms-louisv_b_1577541.html|title=Naked David Storms Louisville as Museum Hotels Raid the Gothic South (PHOTOS, NSFW)|last=Browning|first=Frank|date=2012-06-08|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-12}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/digital-files-and-3d-printingin-the-renaissance-244207/|title=Digital Files and 3D Printing—in the Renaissance?|last=Stamp|first=Jimmy|date=2013-03-01|work=Smithsonian Magazine|access-date=2017-09-12|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/travel/article/louisville-travel-kentucky-derby/index.html|title=A very indulgent guide to Louisville|last=Hunter|first=Marnie|date=2012-05-03|work=CNN Travel|access-date=2017-09-12|language=en}} In ''A Sudden Gust of Wind'' (2007 –2013), Özkaya depicted the journey of a stack of papers blown away by the wind. The original work was made with basic materials: [[ISO 216#A series|standard A4 paper]], thread, and glue. The piece was inspired by ''Ejiri in Suruga Province (A Sudden Gust of Wind)'', a 19th-century Japanese woodcut by [[Hokusai]], and ''A Sudden Gust of Wind (after Hokusai)'' (1993) by [[Jeff Wall]]. One version of the installation was first exhibited at the Boots Contemporary Art Space in St. Louis, Missouri. Another version of the work was acquired by 21c Museum Hotel and installed at their third location in [[Bentonville, Arkansas]]. This version utilizes about 400 metal sheets scattered in a large gallery space.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/life/travel/2013/07/12/an-art-filled-lodging-near-arkansass-crystal-bridges-museum|title=An art-filled lodging near Arkansas's Crystal Bridges museum|last=Jones|first=Michelle|date=2013-07-12|work=Dallas News|access-date=2017-09-12|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-features/news/21c-hotel-launches-in-bentonville-/|title=21c Hotel Launches in Bentonville - News - Art in America|last=Wei|first=Lilly|date=2013-04-26|website=Art in America Magazine|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007110018/http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-features/news/21c-hotel-launches-in-bentonville-/|archive-date=2013-10-07|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-09-12}} [[File:BRING ME THE HEAD OF.JPG|thumb|''Bring me the head of...'' at Freemans' Restaurant as part of [[Performa (performance festival)|Performa07]]]] ''Bring me the head of…'' (2007–2015) is the edible form of a teddy bear's head on a plate. Instead of working with museums or galleries, in this series, Özkaya collaborated with restaurants and chefs and they decided the ingredients—that is the material of the sculpture. This work was made in collaboration with [[M on the Bund]] in [[Shanghai]],{{Cite web|url=http://v3.arkitera.com/arsgratiaartis.php?action=displayNewsItem&ID=20470|title=Serkan Özkaya yeni heykeli ile Şanghay'da|last=|first=|date=2007-09-24|website=Arkitera.com|access-date=2017-09-12}} offered at Freemans' Restaurant in New York in 2007 as a part of the [[Performa (performance festival)|Performa Biennial]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.p-e-r-f-o-r-m-a-n-c-e.org/?p=2578|title=With every bite, a bit of history|last=Goldberg|first=Roselee|date=2016|website=p-e-r-f-o-r-m-a-n-c-e|access-date=2017-09-12}}{{Cite web|url=http://zine.artcat.com/2007/11/bring-me-the-head-of-serkan-ozkaya.php|title=Bring Me the Head of Serkan Özkaya|last=Vartanian|first=Hrag|date=2007-11-28|website=Artcat|language=en|access-date=2017-09-12}} at Changa in Istanbul in 2008, as street food in [[İzmir|Izmir]] in 2009,{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} at Capital M in [[Beijing]] in 2012,{{Cite web|url=https://www.thebeijinger.com/blog/2012/05/25/art-attack-oklahoma-moves-bookstore-opens-exhibits-close-and-wanda-buys-amc|title=Art Attack: Oklahoma! Moves, Bookstore Opens, Exhibits Close and Wanda Buys AMC|last=Mai|first=Marilyn|date=2012-05-25|website=The Beijinger|access-date=2017-09-12}} and at the Hive in [[Bentonville, Arkansas]] in 2014.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} In ''One and Three Pasta'' (2012), Özkaya collaborated with the architect George L. Legendre, a professor at Harvard University.{{Cite news|url=http://magazine.art21.org/2012/08/17/double-or-nothing-an-interview-with-serkan-ozkaya/|title=Double Or Nothing: An Interview with Serkan Ozkaya|last=Wolfson|first=Elizabeth|date=2012-08-17|work=Art21 Magazine|access-date=2017-09-12|language=en-US}} They created a series of replicas using computer models of 92 [[List of pasta|types of pasta]] (based on Legendreʼs mathematical equations).{{Cite news|url=http://www.alexandrapechman.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/Budd-Hopkins.pdf|title=Serkan Özkaya and George L. Legendre: Postmasters|last=McClemont|first=Doug|date=June 2014|work=ARTnews|access-date=2017-09-12}} The actual pieces of pasta were displayed next to their ideal replicas in [[nylon]] along with the generative equations for the shape. One and Three Pasta references to canonical works like [[Joseph Kosuth]]ʼs [[One and Three Chairs]]{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XJoRBwAAQBAJ|title=Imagine Math 3: Between Culture and Mathematics|last=Legendre|first=George L.|date=2015-03-04|publisher=Springer|year=|isbn=9783319012315|editor-last=Emmer|editor-first=Michele|location=|pages=|language=en|chapter=Past Mathematica}} and [[Donald Judd]]ʼs Untitled stacks.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} ''An Attempt at Exhausting A Place…'' is a series of works in which the artist "dissolves the white cube" and the usual constraints of a traditional art space. Four projectors are used to display a live feed of the scene beyond the wall on which they are projected.{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/market/serkan-c3zkaya-dissolves-white-cube-512771|title=Serkan Özkaya Dissolves the White Cube {{!}} artnet News|last=Gopnik|first=Blake|date=2016-06-07|work=artnet News|access-date=2017-09-12|language=en-US}} The work was exhibited as part of Özkaya's solo exhibition at the [[Postmasters Gallery]] in New York,{{Cite news|url=http://observer.com/2016/05/weekend-edition-10-things-to-do-in-new-yorks-art-world-before-may-16/|title=Weekend Edition: 10 Things to Do in New York's Art World Before May 16|last=Laster|first=Paul|date=2016-05-12|work=Observer|access-date=2017-09-12|language=en-US}} running from May 14 to June 18, 2016. In a similar installation at [[İstanbul Modern]], a projection on one its interior walls treated the view to a scene of the [[Bosphorus|Bosphorus Strait]], making the wall seem transparent.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailysabah.com/arts-culture/2017/02/10/istanbul-moderns-harbor-exhibition-focuses-on-citys-kinship-with-sea|title=Istanbul Modern's 'HARBOR' exhibition focuses on city's kinship with sea|last=|first=|date=2017-02-09|work=DailySabah|access-date=2017-09-12}} A version of the work is also presented in a permanent exhibition at the lobby of the 21c Museum Hotel in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].{{Cite news|url=http://artfcity.com/2017/06/19/a-museum-chain-is-local-and-also-a-hotel/|title=A Museum Chain is Local, and Also a Hotel|last=Johnson|first=Paddy|date=2017-06-19|work=Art F City|access-date=2017-09-12|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/life/arts/2017/07/09/21-c-museum-hotel-nashvilles-inaugural-exhibition-seeks-the-truth/455371001/|title=21c Museum Hotel Nashville's inaugural exhibition seeks 'the truth'|last=Baker|first=Milinda|date=2017-07-09|work=The Tennessean|access-date=2017-09-12|language=en}} === Other notable works === ''Atlas'' (2011) is a contribution to a walking museum wherein Özkaya constructed a rock to be strapped to the curator's back and promenaded daily throughout the streets of New York. The idea was to make "the museum" itself wander around the streets of the city with Özkaya's new piece, a giant rock. ''Radisson/Picasso'' (2012), a pair of [[Radisson Hotels|Radisson Hotel]] matchboxes with the text of one of which has been changed to read "Picasso" instead of "Radisson" and was displayed alongside the original.{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/digital/friday-photo-radissonpicasso/|title=Friday Photo: Radisson/Picasso|last=Murg|first=Stephanie|date=2012-03-23|work=AdWeek|access-date=2017-09-08|language=en-US}} ''Mirage'' (2013) was installed at the Postmasters Gallery in New York and consisted of a shadow of a passenger airplane that crossed the room for 45 seconds every four minutes.{{Cite news|url=https://hyperallergic.com/76818/a-shadowy-plane-in-the-cave/|title=A Shadowy Plane in the Cave|last=Vartanian|first=Hrag|date=2013-07-31|work=Hyperallergic|access-date=2017-09-08|language=en-US}} The shadow here was considered not as the mere absence of light but rather as a material in and of itself which could then be sculpted. The work was also exhibited as part of the Borusan Contemporary Art Collection's Overture: New Acquisitions (2015) at [[Perili Köşk]] in Istanbul.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailysabah.com/arts-culture/2014/12/03/two-new-exhibitions-open-at-borusan-contemporary|title=Two new exhibitions open at Borusan Contemporary|last=|first=|date=2014-12-03|work=DailySabah|access-date=2017-09-08}} ''MyMoon'' (2015 – present) is another artwork by Özkaya, a large round rock floating in the sky, that is visible only through a [[smartphone]] via the MyMoon app. Using the phone's GPS and compass, MyMoon app detects the object in the sky and makes it visible. MyMoon rotates in close proximity to the earth's moon in the sky.{{Cite web|url=http://bonemagazine.com/en/entry/istanbul-comics-art-festival|title=Istanbul Comics & Art Festival|last=Yıldız|first=Itır|date=|website=Bone Magazine|access-date=2017-09-08}}{{dead link|date=June 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Yet unlike the earth's satellite, it is visible outdoors and indoors.{{Cite web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/xyg84n/if-apple-cares-so-much-about-design-why-does-the-app-store-ignore-artists|title=If Apple Cares So Much About Design, Why Does the App Store Ignore Artists?|last=Pangburn|first=DJ|date=2015-11-13|website=Motherboard|language=en-us|access-date=2017-09-08}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.popmatters.com/post/why-the-apple-app-store-needs-an-art-category/|title=Why the Apple App Store Needs an Art Category|last=Miller|first=Sean|date=2015-11-16|work=PopMatters|access-date=2017-09-08}} In October 2017, Özkaya presented his latest major work ''En attendons'' (''We Will Wait'') at the Postmasters Gallery. The work is a recreation of [[Marcel Duchamp]]'s ''[[Étant donnés]]'' from which Özkaya's also gets its name in [[anagram]] form.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/29/arts/design/now-you-see-him-now-you-dont-duchamp-from-beyond-the-grave.html|title=Now You See Him, Now You Don’t: Duchamp From Beyond the Grave|last=Mewshaw|first=Marc|date=2017-09-29|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-06|language=en-US}} Özkaya claims to have discovered a secret hidden within Duchamp's piece.{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/duchamp-etant-donnes-secret-serkan-ozkaya-1103216|title=Has Duchamp’s Final Work Harbored a Secret for Five Decades?|last=Boucher|first=Brian|date=2017-10-03|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-03-06|language=en-US}} He proposes that it is not only a [[peephole]] into a [[diorama]] but that, under proper lighting, it also functions as a [[camera obscura]] that projects the French artist's self-portrait on a surface opposite the peephole. According to Özkaya, there is more to ''Étant Donnés'' than previously thought; that the work, which took Duchamp more than 20 years to create,{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/art-and-architecture/privy-to-the-secrets-of-marcel-duchamp/article37436946/|title=A century later, Marcel Duchamp's Fountain continues to beguile the art world|last=Smith|first=Russell|date=December 27, 2017|work=The Globe and Mail|access-date=2018-05-09}} projects an image of Rrose Sélavy, "Duchamp’s female alter ego."{{Cite web|url=https://www.theparisreview.org/blog/2017/10/18/duchamps-last-riddle/|title=Duchamp’s Last Riddle|last=Steinhauer|first=Jillian|date=2017-10-18|website=The Paris [[File:Vincent van Gogh - Sorrow.jpg|thumb|''[[Sorrow (Van Gogh)|Sorrow]]'', drawing by [[Vincent van Gogh]], 1882]] {{emotion}} '''Sorrow''' is an [[emotion]], feeling, or sentiment. Sorrow "is more 'intense' than [[sadness]]... it implies a long-term state".<ref>Anna Wierzbicka, ''Emotions across Languages and Cultures'' (1999) p. 66</ref> At the same time "sorrow — but not unhappiness — suggests a degree of resignation... which lends sorrow its peculiar air of dignity".<ref name="Wierzbicka, p. 66">Wierzbicka, p. 66</ref>
Moreover, "in terms of attitude, sorrow can be said to be half way between ''sadness'' (accepting) and ''distress'' (not accepting)".<ref name="Wierzbicka, p. 66"/>
==Cult== [[Romanticism]] saw a cult of sorrow develop, reaching back to ''[[The Sorrows of Young Werther]]'' of 1774, and extending through the nineteenth century with contributions like [[Alfred, Lord Tennyson|Tennyson]]'s "[[In Memoriam A.H.H.|In Memoriam]]" — "O Sorrow, wilt thou live with me/No casual mistress, but a wife"<ref>''In Memoriam'' (London 1851) p. 84</ref> — up to [[W. B. Yeats]] in 1889, still "of his high comrade Sorrow dreaming".<ref>W. B. Yeats, ''The Poems'' (London 1983) p. 8</ref> While it may be that "the [[Romantic hero]]'s cult of sorrow is largely a matter of pretence",<ref>Lilian R. Furst, ''Romanticism in Perspective'' (1979) p. 102-3</ref> as [[Jane Austen]] pointed out satirically through [[Marianne Dashwood]], "brooding over her sorrows... this excess of suffering"<ref>Jane Austen, ''Sense and Sensibility'' (London 1932) p. 183 and p. 157</ref> may nevertheless have serious consequences.
Partly in reaction, the 20th century has by contrast been pervaded by the belief that "''acting'' sorrowful can actually make me sorrowful, as William James long ago observed".<ref>Jenefer Robinson, ''Deeper than Reason'' (2005) p. 82</ref> Certainly "in the modern Anglo-emotional culture, characterized by the 'dampening of the emotions' in general... sorrow has largely given way to the milder, less painful, and more transient sadness".<ref>Wierzbicka, p. 67</ref> A latter-day Werther is likely to be greeted by the call to '"Come off it, Gordon. We all know there is no sorrow like unto your sorrow"';<ref>C. P. Snow, ''Last Things'' (Penguin 1974) p. 251</ref> while any conventional 'valeoftearishness and deathwhereisthystingishness' would be met by the participants 'looking behind the sombre backs of one another's cards and discovering their {{Sic|?|hide=y|brightly|-}}colored faces'.<ref>Günter Grass, ''The Meeting at Telgte'' (London 1981) p. 94</ref> Perhaps only the occasional subculture like the [[Jung]]ian would still seek to 'call up from the busy adult man the sorrow of animal life, the grief of all nature, "the tears of things"'.<ref>Robert Bly, ''Iron John'' (Dorset 1991) p. 239</ref>
[[Late modernity]] has (if anything) only intensified the shift: 'the postmodern is closer to the human comedy than to the abyssal discontent...the abyss of sorrow'.<ref>Julia Kristeva, ''Black Sun'' (New York 1989) p. 258-9 and p. 3</ref>
==Postponement== 'Not feeling sorrow invites fear into our lives. The longer we put off feeling sorrow, the greater our fear of it becomes. [[Postponement of affect|Postponing]] the expression of the feeling causes its energy to grow'.<ref>Erika M. Hunter, ''Little Book of Big Emotions'' (London 2004) p. 115</ref> At the same time, it would seem that 'grief in general is a "taming" of the primitive violent discharge affect, characterized by fear and self-destruction, to be seen in mourning'.<ref>Otto Fenichel, ''The Psychoanalytic Theory of Neurosis'' (London 19460 p. 395</ref>
[[Julia Kristeva]] suggests that 'taming sorrow, not fleeing sadness at once but allowing it to settle for a while...is what one of the temporary and yet indispensable phases of [[Psychoanalysis|analysis]] might be'.<ref>Kristeva, p. 84-5</ref>
==Shand and McDougall== Sadness is one of four interconnected ''sentiments'' in the system of [[Alexander Faulkner Shand]], the others being fear, anger, and joy. In this system, when an impulsive tendency towards some important object is frustrated, the resultant sentiment is sorrow.<ref>{{cite book|pages=73|chapter=Sentiments, Character, Free Will|title=Ethical Problems|author=Beatrice Edgell|location=London|publisher=Methuen & Co. Ltd|date=1929}}</ref>
In Shand's view, the emotion of sorrow, which he classifies as a primary emotion, has two ''impulses'': to cling to the object of sorrow, and to repair the injuries done to that object that caused the emotion in the first place. Thus the primary emotion of sorrow is the basis for the emotion of pity, which Shand describes as a fusion of sorrow and joy: sorrow at the injury done to the object of pity, and joy as an "element of sweetness" tinging that sorrow.<ref name=McDougall>{{cite book|title=Introduction To Social Psychology|author=[[William McDougall (psychologist)|William McDougall]]|publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Distributors|date=1994|isbn=9788171564965|pages=68–69}}</ref>
[[William McDougall (psychologist)|William McDougall]] disagreed with Shand's view, observing that Shand himself recognized that sorrow was itself derived from simpler elements. To support this argument, he observes that [[grief]], at a loss, is a form of sorrow where there is no impulse to repair injury, and that therefore there are identifiable subcomponents of sorrow. He also observes that although there is an element of emotional pain in sorrow, there is no such element in pity, thus pity is not a compound made from sorrow as a simpler component.<ref name=McDougall />

{{See also|Solar radiation management}}
A '''space sunshade''' or '''sunshield''' is a [[Umbrella|parasol]] that [[wikt:divert|divert]]s or otherwise reduces some of a star's radiation, preventing them from hitting a spacecraft or planet and thereby reducing its [[insolation]], which results in reduced heating. Light can be diverted by different methods. First proposed in 1989, the original space sunshade concept involves putting a large occulting disc, or technology of equivalent purpose at the L1 gravitation point ([[Lagrangian point]]) between the Earth and Sun.
A sunshade is of particular interest as a [[climate engineering]] method for [[Climate change mitigation|mitigating]] [[global warming]] through [[solar radiation management]]. Heightened interest in such projects reflects the concern that internationally negotiated reductions in carbon emissions may be insufficient to stem climate change.<ref>Hickman, John. "The Political Economy of a Planetary Sunshade" Astropolitics: The International Journal of Space Politics and Policy (2018): 16(1):1-10. Retrieved 3-30-18.</ref> Sunshades could also be used to produce [[space solar power]], acting as [[solar power satellites]]. Proposed shade designs include a single-piece shade and a shade made by a great number of small objects. Most such proposals contemplate a blocking element at the Sun-Earth L1 [[Lagrangian point]].
In 1989 James Early proposed a space-based sun-shade to divert sunlight at the planetary level. His design involved making a large glass (2000 km) occulter from lunar material and placing at the L1 point. Issues included the large amount of material needed to make the disc and also the energy to launch it to its orbit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20160425-how-a-giant-space-umbrella-could-stop-global-warming|title=How a giant space umbrella could stop global warming|last=Gorvett|first=Zaria|access-date=2016-12-13}}</ref>
==Designs for planetary sunshade==
=== Cloud of small spacecraft === One proposed sunshade would be composed of 16 trillion small disks at the Sun-Earth L1 [[Lagrangian point]], 1.5 million kilometers above Earth. Each disk is proposed to have a 0.6-meter diameter and a thickness of about 5 micrometers. The mass of each disk would be about a gram, adding up to a total of almost 20 million tonnes.<ref>{{cite web | title =Space sunshade might be feasible in global warming emergency | work = | publisher =EurekAlert | date =2006-11-03 | url =http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2006-11/uoa-ssm110306.php | format = | doi = | accessdate =2010-11-11 }}</ref> Such a group of small sunshades that blocks 2% of the sunlight, deflecting it off into space, would be enough to halt global warming, giving us ample time to cut our emissions back on earth.<ref>{{cite web | title =Global Sunshade | work = | publisher =BBC News | date =2007-02-19 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/picture_gallery/07/programmes_global_sunshade/html/1.stm | format = | doi = | accessdate =2010-11-11 }}</ref>
The individual autonomous flyers building up the cloud of sunshades are proposed not to reflect the sunlight but rather to be transparent lenses, deflecting the light slightly so it does not hit Earth. This minimizes the effect of [[solar radiation pressure]] on the units, requiring less effort to hold them in place at the L1 point. An optical prototype has been constructed by [[Roger Angel]] with funding from [[NASA Institute for Advanced Concepts|NIAC]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Tnenbaum | first = David | title = Pies in the Sky: A Solution to Global Warming | work = | publisher =Astrobiology Magazine | date =2007-04-23 | url =http://www.astrobio.net/news-exclusive/pies-in-the-sky-a-solution-to-global-warming/ | format = | doi = | accessdate =2010-11-14 }}</ref>
The remaining solar pressure and the fact that the L1 point is one of [[unstable equilibrium]], easily disturbed by the wobble of the earth due to gravitational effects from the moon, requires the small autonomous flyers to be capable of maneuvering themselves to hold position. A suggested solution is to place mirrors capable of rotation on the surface of the flyers. By using the solar radiation pressure on the mirrors as [[solar sail]]s and tilting them in the right direction, the flyer will be capable of altering its speed and direction to keep in position.<ref name = "L1_cooling">{{cite web | last = Angel | first = Roger | title = Feasibility of cooling the Earth with a cloud of small spacecraft near the inner Lagrange point (L1) | work = | publisher =PNAS | date =2006-09-18 | url = http://www.pnas.org/content/103/46/17184.full#sec-7 | format = | doi = | accessdate =2010-11-14 }}</ref>
Such a group of sunshades would need to occupy an area of about 3.8 million square kilometers if placed at the L1 point.<ref name = "L1_cooling" /> The deployment of the flyers is an issue that requires new technology. Large [[railgun]]s or [[coilgun]]s are proposed to fire a capsule containing a million shades into space every 5 minutes for 10 years using 20 separate launch sites.
Even so, it would still take years to launch enough of the disks into [[orbit]] to have any effect. This means a long [[lead time]]. Roger Angel of the University of Arizona<ref>{{cite web| last=Stiles| first=Lori| title=Space sunshade might be feasible in global warming emergency| url=http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2006-11/uoa-ssm110306.php| work="Feasibility of cooling the Earth with a cloud of small spacecraft near L1,"| publisher=Eurekalert| accessdate=2011-04-28}}</ref> presented the idea for a sunshade at the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|U.S. National Academy of Sciences]] in April 2006 and won a [[NASA]] Institute for Advanced Concepts grant for further research in July 2006.
Creating this sunshade in space was estimated to cost in excess of US$5 trillion with an estimated lifetime of 50 years.<ref>{{cite web | last =Fisher | first =David | title =Sunshade in space | work = | publisher =Australian Broadcasting Corporation | date =2006-11-11 | url =http://www.abc.net.au/rn/scienceshow/stories/2006/1785912.htm | doi = | accessdate =2010-11-11 }}</ref> Thus leading Professor Angel to conclude that "[t]he sunshade is no substitute for developing [[renewable energy]], the only permanent solution. A similar massive level of technological innovation and financial investment could ensure that. But if the planet gets into an abrupt climate crisis that can only be fixed by cooling, it would be good to be ready with some shading solutions that have been worked out."<ref name="L1_cooling"/><ref name="Earth Observatory 2006-11-03">{{cite press release |title=Space Sunshade Might Be Feasible In Global Warming Emergency |url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Newsroom/view.php?id=31280 |publisher=University of Arizona |date = 2006-11-06 |accessdate = 2009-04-29 }}</ref>
===One Fresnel lens=== [[Image:Space lens.png|thumb|right|300px|The basic function of a space lens to mitigate global warming. A 1,000-kilometre diameter lens is sufficient, and much smaller than what is shown in this simplified image. As a [[Fresnel lens]] it would be only a few millimeters thick.]]
Several authors have proposed dispersing light before it reaches the Earth by putting a very large lens in space, perhaps at the [[Lagrangian point#L1|L1]] point between the Earth and the Sun. This plan was proposed in 1989 by J. T. Early.<ref name="Early">{{Citation |author=J. T. Early |title=Space-Based Solar Shield To Offset Greenhouse Effect |year=1989 |periodical=Journal of the British Interplanetary Society |volume=42 |pages=567–569|bibcode = 1989JBIS...42..567E }}. This proposal is also discussed in footnote 23 of {{Citation |author1=Edward Teller |author2=Roderick Hyde |author3=Lowell Wood |last-author-amp=yes |title=Global Warming and Ice Ages: Prospects for Physics-Based Modulation of Global Change |year=1997 |format=PDF |publisher=Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory |url=https://e-reports-ext.llnl.gov/pdf/231636.pdf |accessdate=2010-10-30}}.</ref>
In 2004, physicist and science fiction author [[Gregory Benford]] calculated that a [[concave lens|concave]] rotating [[Fresnel lens]] 1000 kilometres across, yet only a few millimeters thick, floating in space at the {{L1}} point, would reduce the solar energy reaching the Earth by approximately 0.5% to 1%.<ref name="Benford1">See [http://www.kuro5hin.org/story/2005/4/7/41932/19363 Russell Dovey, "Supervillainy: Astroengineering Global Warming] and [http://www.technovelgy.com/ct/Science-Fiction-News.asp?NewsNum=370 Bill Christensen, "Reduce Global Warming by Blocking Sunlight"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417153949/http://www.technovelgy.com/ct/Science-Fiction-News.asp?NewsNum=370 |date=2009-04-17 }}.</ref>
The cost of such a lens has been disputed. At a science fiction convention in 2004, Benford estimated that it would cost about [[United States dollar|US$]]10 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] up front, and another $10 billion in supportive cost during its lifespan.<ref name="Benford1"/>
===One diffraction grating=== A similar approach involves placing a very large [[diffraction grating]] (thin wire mesh) in space, perhaps at the [[Lagrangian point#L1|L1]] point between the Earth and the Sun. A proposal for a 3,000 ton diffraction mesh was made in 1997 by [[Edward Teller]], [[Lowell Wood]], and [[Roderick Hyde]],<ref name="Teller1997">{{Citation |author1=Edward Teller |author2=Roderick Hyde |author3=Lowell Wood |last-author-amp=yes |title=Global Warming and Ice Ages: Prospects for Physics-Based Modulation of Global Change |year=1997 |format=PDF |publisher=Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory |url=https://e-reports-ext.llnl.gov/pdf/231636.pdf |accessdate=2010-10-30}}. See pages 10–14 in particular.</ref> although in 2002 these same authors argued for blocking solar radiation in the stratosphere rather than in orbit given then-current space launch technologies.<ref name="Teller2002">{{Citation |author1=Edward Teller, Roderick Hyde |author2=Lowell Wood |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Active Climate Stabilization: Practical Physics-Based Approaches to Prevention of Climate Change |year=2002 |format=PDF |publisher=Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory |url=https://e-reports-ext.llnl.gov/pdf/244671.pdf |accessdate=2010-10-30}}.</ref>
==Spacecraft sunshades== The [[James Webb Space Telescope]] (JWST) infrared telescope has a layered sunshade to keep the telescope cold.
For spacecraft approaching the sun the sunshade is usually called a heatshield. Notable spacecraft [designs] with heatshields include : * [[Parker Solar Probe]] (was Solar Probe Plus), launched 2018 (carbon, carbon-foam, carbon sandwich heatshield) * [[Solar Orbiter]], may launch 2020 * [[Messenger (spacecraft)|Messenger]], orbits Mercury, has a ceramic cloth sunshade * [[BepiColumbo]], to orbit Mercury, with Optical Solar Reflectors (acting as a sunshade) on the Planetary Orbiter component.
